The Cabinet resumed the discussion begun thesame morning on the question of the proposed taxation of Co-operative Societies . They were reminded thatin his Budget Statement last year the Chancellor ofthe Exchequer had laid some stress on the importanceof reaching an agreement on this long-standing issue,and this had been one of the principal objects forwhich the Committee had been set up.While there was a general recognition that theReport of the Committee could not be set aside withoutgood reason, the Cabinet were informed that theCommittee's Report would not meet with general aecept-ance and that its adoption would not lead to a perman-ent settlement. It was recalled that an attempt toreach an agreement with the Co-operative Societieson the basis of the Report failed owing to theopposition of the political elements . It was recog-nised also that not much money was involved in the taxation proposals of the Committee.In these circumstances the question was mootedas to whether it was worth while to raise thepolitical difficulties involved in implementing theReport . In this connection the Cabinet were reminded that Parliamentary opinion on this subject was divided, but not exclusively on Party lines. Thiswas reflected to some extent In the discussions ofthe Cabinet itself, although there was an earnestdesire on all sides to find some just solution thatwould meet the very real difficulties of both points of view. It was recognised that if the Co-operative societies were not subjected to any further IncomeTax the grievances of the retail traders would notbe met: while, on the other hand, if the report were adopted in extenso the Co-operative Societies -would, protest that their principle of mutuality wasinfringed,The Chancellor of the Exchequer (to whose concilia-tory attitude members of the Cabinet paid warmtributes) enquired whether it might not still bepossible to find some reasonable basis of agreementwith the Co-operative Societies . The Cabinet wereadvised, however, by those members who were best ableto gauge the position, that, judged by the failure of previous efforts to find, an accommodation, there wasno reasonable prospect of a successful negotiation onthe merits of the case. More especially after the big effort that had been made by the Co-operative societies on the previous day to exert pressure on individual Members of Parliament by mass propaganda,it was felt that any overtures were likely to betreated merely as a symptom of weakness . No memberof the Cabinet was disposed to yield to such methods.In these circumstances it was felt that if some reasonable solution could be found which was acceptable to the Cabinet as a whole, it would be better topresent it to Parliament as the decision of theGovernment.In the course of a prolonged discussion, whichranged over the aspects of law, equity, finance and policy, various tentative suggestions were made for asolution: for example, to tax trading profits of stores on sales to non-members, which was stated to be practicable and not unacceptable to the Co-operative societies, while going some way to meet the grievancesof private traders: or to find some system whichwould enable the Co-operative Societies to compoundtheir taxation, as had been done in the case ofBuilding Societies , The Chancellor of the Exchequer undertook toexamine the question with his Department in thelight of the discussion and to see if he could find some basis for a settlement, and to report to theCabinet, if possible, at their next Meeting, rppIB BATTERS FAPOWER STATION,(previous reference cabinet 23(33), Con-elusion 10.)2.
